official-title.#text:
To set forth the process for Puerto Rico to be admitted
		  as a State of the Union.

cosponsor.#tail:
) introduced the
			 following bill; which was referred to the

text.#text: This Act may be cited as the

In 1898, Puerto Rico became a United States
			 territory and persons born in Puerto Rico have been granted United States
			 citizenship by law since March 2, 1917.

Puerto Rico has been granted authority over
			 local matters that is similar to the authority that the several States possess,
			 but Puerto Rico remains subject to the powers of Congress under the Territory
			 Clause of the Constitution of the United States.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Vice President of the United States

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
, and their one representative in
			 the

can only vote in committees of the
			 United States House of Representatives.

text.#text:
The approximately 3,700,000 residents of
			 Puerto Rico do not have a democratic form of government at the national level,
			 because United States citizens residing in the territory are disenfranchised in
			 the election for the

The Federal
			 Government may—and often does—treat Puerto Rico and its residents unequally
			 under Federal program, tax, and other laws relative to the several States and
			 the District of Columbia and their residents.

quote.#tail:
. Of the 1,798,987 voters who chose an option, 53.97 percent
			 voted against continued territorial status.
quote.#text:
should continue to have its present form of territorial
			 status

text.#text:
On November 6, 2012, the Government of
			 Puerto Rico held a two-part referendum. The first question asked voters if
			 Puerto Rico

The second
			 question asked voters to express their preference among the three possible
			 alternatives to territorial status: statehood, independence, and nationhood in
			 free association with the United States. Of the 1,363,854 voters who chose an
			 option, 61.16 percent voted for statehood.

The number of
			 votes cast in favor of statehood exceeded the number of votes cast in favor of
			 continued territorial status.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
shall take to enable the admission of Puerto Rico as a State of
			 the Union.

text.#text:
The purpose of this Act is to provide for a
			 federally authorized ratification vote in Puerto Rico on the admission of
			 Puerto Rico into the Union as a State and, if a majority of voters ratify
			 Puerto Rico’s desire for statehood, to describe the steps that the

The State Elections
			 Commission of Puerto Rico is authorized to provide for a ratification vote on
			 the admission of Puerto Rico into the Union as a State, in accordance with
			 rules and regulations determined by the Commission, including qualifications
			 for voter eligibility, with the following on the ballot:

continuation-text.#text:
Do you
				want Puerto Rico to be admitted as a State of the United States? Yes__
				No__

text.#text:
As a
				State:

Puerto Rico would be permanently united to
				the other States of the Union.

All provisions of the Constitution of the
				United States that apply to the States would apply to Puerto Rico.

Individuals born
				in Puerto Rico would be United States citizens by virtue of the Constitution of
				the United States, instead of by virtue of laws of the United States.

Puerto Rico would
				be treated equally with the other States in all Federal laws of general
				application.

There would be a
				period of transition to statehood, during which equal treatment of Puerto Rico
				in program and tax laws would be phased in.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
by a number of Representatives in proportion to
				its share of the national population (and the number of Members of the House of
				Representatives would be increased by the same number), and for the election of
				the

by a number of votes
				in the Electoral College equal to the number of its Senators and
				Representatives.
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Vice President of the United States

text.#text:
Puerto Rico would
				be represented in the United States Senate by two Senators, in the

The Government of Puerto Rico, like the
				governments of the other States, would have permanent authority over all
				matters not delegated to the Federal Government or the people by the
				Constitution of the United States.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
, not later than 180 days
			 after the certification of the vote, shall submit to

legislation to
			 admit Puerto Rico as a State of the Union on an equal footing with the several
			 States in all respects, consistent with the terms of this Act.

text.#text:
If a majority of votes
			 cast in the ratification vote held under section 3 are for the admission of
			 Puerto Rico as a State of the Union, the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
to act, through legislation, to admit Puerto Rico as a State of the
			 Union on an equal footing with the several States in all respects, consistent
			 with the terms of this Act.
